headline: Gluehwein
description: This glühwein recipe for hot spiced red wine is made with cinnamon, orange, and cloves for an easy, warming beverage that makes you feel cozy all over.
name: Gluehwein

recipeInstructions.text: Combine water, sugar, and cinnamon stick in a saucepan; bring to a boil. Reduce heat to low.

Cut one orange in half; squeeze orange halves over the sugar mixture to release their juice. Push 5 cloves into the outside of each orange peel; place peels into the simmering mixture. Continue to simmer over the lowest heat until thick and syrupy, 20 to 30 minutes.
While the mixture is simmering, slice remaining orange and set aside for serving.
When the mixture is finished simmering, stir in wine and heat until steaming but not simmering, 3 to 5 minutes. Discard orange peels and cinnamon stick.
Ladle into mugs and garnish with orange slices.

review.reviewBody: Tasted just like the Glühwein I had in the Christmas markets in Belgium and Germany! Perfect!
Made this for the first time this year and loved it! Not overly sweet and just enough spice to warm you up on these chilly winter nights!
This is my go to recipe! I have been making glühwein with this recipe for at least 10 yrs! Simple and excellent! Never fails
My husband is picky and even he loved it. And so simple.

Merry Christmas to all! 

I made a double batch of the recipe but swapped the 1.5 cups of sugar with 36 packets of Stevia to reduce calories.

It was easy and actually took less time to turn to syrup.

Ausgezeichnet!! Vergelt’s Gott!

Excellent! I also added anise and a few pods of cardamom. Also, I used a shiraz and cut the sugar down to a little less than 1/2 cup. It was a good decision, 3/4 cup of sugar would have been too much.
Delicious! I added some star anise and a few cardamom pods, and reduced the sugar by half. This is a favorite for sure!
Me and the neighbors LOVED this sitting outside handing out Halloween candy. Will be making this again!
It is EXACTLY like the original you can buy in stores. Will definitely be saving this recipe.
I always thought mulled wine to be a waste of red wine. So I made this with white wine. Still delicious!
Added peppercorn!
This was very easy to make but was far too sweet for our tastes. I used a Chilean carmenere for the wine.
This was too sweet for my taste.

I’ve never had mulled wine that I liked until I tried this. Fantastic! I added a bit of Cointreau and was careful not to let things boil. 

My suggestion: make more than you think you need if you want extra for later; you’ll likely not have leftovers.
I’ve never made anything like this and it was delicious. Definitely in my favorites file. I added a handful of fresh cranberries it was really yummy!
We recommend cutting the sugar in half. We squeezed 4 mandarins instead of an orange. The outcome tasted like Glühwein in Bavaria. Proßt!
Delicious! Reminds of the winter festival in Switzerland!!!

This recipe is a holiday tradition for me! It’s so simple to make yet amazingly authentic. After living in Germany for three years, I had to find a good recipe for Gluehwein and I found it with this. Thank you!
Seir gutt. very tasty version of my days in Austria
This recipe is perfect, I've been making it for a couple years now. It's now a family tradition to make this on Thanksgiving and Christmas.
So yummy, I wanted to drink all of it, but I shared it anyway. I will make it again.
I’ve been making this for several years in the winter and my family loves it! It’s easy to make and makes a great gift!

Used this recipe for this year’s Christmas party and it was loved by all! Doubled all the ingredients since there were about 12 guests. Keep the evaporation in mind and accordingly add a little bit more water and wine.

Tasty! I used the juice of 2 oranges, omitted boiling the orange halves in the syrup, substituted 1/8 teaspoon ground cloves for the whole cloves, and used 3 cinnamon sticks. Made this way the recipe tastes like the beverage sold in the Chicago Christkindlmarkt.

Growing up in Germany I drank gluhwein every Christmas, and this comes very very close to the real thing. I just remember it being a little stronger, maybe they added a bit more "umpf" in my hometown haha
Used the water, not OJ. This was really good. Reminded me of my days in Austria.
I used a good cabernet sauvignon. Came out fantastic!

Just got back from Germany and wanted Gluhwein like from the Christmas markets. This is very good. I didn't even have whole cinnamon or cloves so I used my regular powdered spices and I could not feel any gritty spice in my drink. I would use whole spices for company and nice glass cups but plan to keep using my giant economy size cinnamon for personal use this winter.

This was just like the Traditional Gluhwein I had Wiesbaden Germany at a Christmas Market last week. I made a double batch and added some allspice berries. It was not quite sweet enough so I added a little cranberry juice and it was perfect!
As is, will most definitely make it again!
have made this several times, and love it! i tend to add spiced rum into my mug before i pour the recipe in, as i like the extra alcohol. delicious with and without!
As a German Immigrant I am very familiar with this drink. My family always drinks it on Christmas Eve as traditional festivities Very delicious
Great easy recipe that tastes fantastic when done. Just like in Austria!

My mom is from Germany and she always made this for Christmas eve when we opened presents. Unfortunately, she had gotten to an age where she doesn't remember what the measurements were. This tasted just like how she made it. The only thing different was she didn't add the orange but I am sure it is a nice touch. Thanks for sharing and keeping our Christmas Eve tradition.
Good. Used a bottle of Merlot. Best when very warm.
This is the second time making this for entertaining friends. It's always a big hit!
Reminds me of Germany in the winter time!
Big hit at our Christmas party!

I use red velvet red wine. I followed are other recommendations to use orange juice in place of water. Some of our guests commented that the wine actually tasted better on ice. I noticed it got sweeter towards the bottom. A reminder to give it a stir while serving it. I will be making this over and over.
Came out perfect! I didn't have any whole cloves and substituted them for 1/2 teaspoon ground clove and it worked great.
Tastes like I remember it. Probably would've saved an hour if I knew to leave the lid off during the simmer/reduction.

Outstanding recipe. As SERVANTMARA suggested, I replaced the water with orange juice for more zest (same quantity) and I used 12 cloves (instead of 10). I used a Bordeaux wine called Louis Eschenauer. It was to die for. I will definitely make this again on Christmas Eve with the family.

Super yummy! I first had Gluehwein at a German Christmas Market here in town and fell in love. This tastes super similar! I'm diabetic so I altered a little bit and doubled the recipe. For 1.5L of Chianti red wine, I used water and only half the sugar...however I used 2 oranges instead of 1 and half a grapefruit. I'm excited to keep experimenting with this base!
So simple to make and soo soo good on a cold winter evening!!! This recipe is going in the box for later!
Tastes exactly like the one we enjoyed in Germany. The quality of the wine matters though, so choose with care.
Simple & delicious... like Christmas in a glass. What's not to love??

Outstanding recipe! My husband and I make our own wine, so. . . I decided I wanted to make a Christmas wine this year. We made a Beaujolais . After it went through its entire fermentation process and was ready for modeling, I then made this recipe to add to it. I multiplied the recipe, cut back a-bit on the oranges and added some of my own other spices! The taste was incredible. After simmering the entire pot we added it to our wine and then bottled two cases for friends and family for Christmas! Here’s hoping they love it as much as we do!
Making it for the second time. It is really good for the holiday season. Made as written with a cheap red table wine and it was delicious.
Just like the Gluehwein we've enjoyed at European Christmas markets. A little extra spice does not go amiss. :)

I followed the rest of the reviewers suggestions and substituted orange juice for the water and it turned out so much better than I could have ever thought. My only complaint is there is no point in making a single batch, its just too good.

Always a huge hit at family gatherings. I use brown sugar instead of white and it never seems to get thick and syrupy but maybe I get too impatient to drink it, it's good nonetheless. I double it and put it in a crockpot.
Way to sweet! I would cut the sugar in half, maybe even more.
I doubled the recipe for a party. Everyone enjoyed it. There was a little left so I poured it back in a wine bottle. I reheated it later and it was still delicious.
As the name indicates, it was a very easy recipe. I did not expect the gluhwein from Christmasmarkt in Germany, but the taste was in the right direction. It was delicious.
We had a bunch of people come over and this was a hit!
This is best done with merlot or pinot noir
Really good! I used OJ instead of water.
Just back from the German Christmas markets and this Gluhwine beats them all. Next Christmas this will be the recipe of choice for all our guests.
I loved it! I also used orange juice instead of water. It was a bit on the sweet side, but the flavor was incredible. It made an excellent christmas drink!

I trippeled the amount for new years eve, fantastic, The pot was empty everybody loved it, great recipe easy to make. . 
We used Yellowtail, red wine.

Fantastic! I've made it 4 times now and have even tripled the recipe. It takes me back to the Weinachtsmarkt in Deutschland and is a huge hit at parties, with family on Christmas and great for New Years too! I make it in a typical pot on the stove and once the wine is added and heated, I strain it into a crockpot to keep warm. I use a Merlot from Gnarly Head. It tastes great and makes you feel so warm and fuzzy.
This was one of the best mulled wine recipes I have tried. Great flavor, I added a little brandy to it as well.

Awesome and easy recipe! Also did not use water, opting for orange juice instead. Overall amazing! Felt like being in Germany all over again! Next time I'll use less sugar and a less expensive bottle of wine.

This recipe is amazing! The only thing I did differently was use orange juice (no pulp) instead of water and I cut the amount sugar in half because I didn't want it too sweet. I also added 5 cardamom pods along with all the other spices. I made it with Cabernet Sauvignon. Everyone loved it and kept going back for more!
Super easy, quick and delicious
This was a hit at my party!
I made it as written, but I quadrupled the recipe for large group. After it was done I put it in a slow cooker on low . There wasn't a drop left at the end of the party. It was a great hit!!

This is the perfect balance of spices to compete with any Christmas market in Germany. I have made it for years and do not change anything. I make the syrup days in advance and mix it with the wine just before the party.
Reduced sugar to 1/2 cup; added a few peppercorns, 1 tsp grated fresh ginger, 2 anise stars and 1/4 tsp cardamom
I used raw can rather than white sugar otherwise followed the simple directions. Unfortunately the orange lacked really good flavor so I did add a splash of juice. It was wonderful.

Served 3 years in Germany and this IS what they sell in the Christmas Market :) Saved all our gluhwein mugs and this does them justice, love it! BTW, if you have a lower-sugar palet, don't make it with orange juice, stick to water :D
Super good! I used a whole orange and a bottle of red wine, tastes amazing!

The flavor of this was great but it was slightly too sweet even though I love sweet wines and desserts....I suggest not replacing the water with orange juice as others suggest and cutting sugar back to 2/3 cup if squeezing the juice of the whole orange in. I used Merlot. Thank you for the recipe!

Tasted exactly like German gluwhein. Really pleased with it. Id change very little but found two cinnamon sticks were nice, a little less sugar and a little more water or replace the extra water with orange juice and it'd be perfect. After cutting the orange in half, put the cloves in the orange halves before squeezing the orange as it becomes much harder to put the cloves in when it's already squeezed.
I used brown sugar. And one more trick. You don't need to warm up a glass if you put a clean tea spoon in it while poring. Then just remove the spoon. Voila!

Absolutely the perfect winter drink! Delicious! The first time we made it with a very nice zin and WOW! The second time we used a cabernet and it was also fantastic! It seems that it doesn't really matter what kind of red you use, which is great. Makes it really versatile. We will definitely keep this recipe!

Things I changed: I used 7 cloves instead of 10. I added 1 cardamom pod. Of the 3/4 cup sugar; I split it 50:50 white sugar, brown sugar. For the red wine: I used a red blend (Llano signature red: Cab sav, merlot, malbec). I thought this was way too sweet. Also, I had mini mandarins, so I used 1.5 of those instead of 1 orange. In my tasting, I thought some almond would be a nice addition. I added a touch of amaretto to the mug, it tasted good. When I make again, I would use 6 tbsp brown sugar and almond slivers, or 4 tbsp brown sugar + 2 tbsp amaretto.
I am from the Northern region of Germany and we serve ours with a shot of SoCo,Amaretto or any other
I use this recipe every Christmas

I'm giving the recipe 5 stars even though mine took extra work to be drinkable! They didn't have either of the red wines I had hoped to use, so I got cupcake merlot. It was not at all like the spiced wine I had at a German restaurant, but I added honey to make it taste okay. I want to make it again with wine I like, because it was the merlot itself that did not taste good. I hoped the spices would fix that, but it didn't.
Delicious and cozy on a winter night. My hubby lived in Germany for a while and he says this is just like the stuff he had there.
Great recipe on a nice cold snowy winter night!
I liked this recipe! I added a little less sugar and I think If I were to make it again I would use maybe half the sugar.

Turned out really good. Though after reading reviews, had done some modifications. Added less water, and replaced it with orange juice. Also, added little bit of nutmeg, star anise and 1/2 inch piece of ginger while boiling the water (step 1). Thank you for sharing the reviews and this amazing recipe!!
It is spelled glühwein, which means so much as wine which makes you glow with warmth

Excellent! Just made it for 2014 Christmas. I wanted to surprise my siblings who joined us at our house since we are of German descent. Everyone loved it! since I make my own homemade wine, I have tried it 3 different ways. But my first batch so far was the best, using Cabernet & Concord with the original recipe. I am definitely starting a new family tradition. WEEZ
Pretty authentic, used orange juice in place of water and it gave a great flavor. Perfect for warming up on a cold winter day.
fantastic!!

Thanks for the recipe! I added another cinnamon stick & a few more cloves. This was perfect! I was missing the spirited German Christmas Markets we experienced last year. Your recipe helped bring some of the cheer to my home this year.
Amazing!

As the recipe stands, I give it 4 stars because I think it's too sweet. But that can be easily rectified by making the sugar syrup as in step 1, setting half of it aside, then continue with the recipe as written. When finished, add more of the reserved sugar syrup (or not) to taste. Forget Christmas, this is wonderful all year long! Oh, and to give this a Swedish twist, serve with raisins and/or slivered almonds in the mug. Absolutely divine.

Each time I visit Germany, I try to make sure it's at a time when I can hit a Weinachtsmarkt and drink glühwein. This is an excellent recipe! I didn't use sugar, but rather six packets of Splenda. I realized this was about 2/3 the sweetness that I would have gotten using the amount of sugar in the recipe, but I figured I could add more later, if need be. (6 packets were just right.) I did strain the glühwein before serving and then just put it back in the pot and set it on the kosher setting on the stove. After all, I didn't want the alcohol to cook off.

I am German and have had lots of Gluehwein in my life, funny enough I never made it myself, since you can simply buy it anywhere in Germany. Since I've been in the US for many years, I looked for a recipe and I really enjoy this home made Gluehwein, it tastes great and authentic and I like that I can vary the ingredients if I want to, such as adding more orange joice, or adding spiced rum.
Thank you so much for sharing this recipe, it brings a piece of home to me :-)

Just came back from Germany and the Christmas markets and we were craving some Gluewien. I also used orange juice instead of the water and added 2 more cinnamon sticks. It was exactly like the Gluewein in Germany this way

Excellent winter drink! Like others I used more OJ than the one orange, but otherwise made as directed. Our au pair from Austria says this is just like what they drink at home. Will be a holiday favorite at our house from now on.
I doubled this recipe using half orange juice and half water. I made this with a cabernet from Sam's. It was a hit! Just like I used to drink in Germany.
The recipe, as is, is a bit too sweet for me. I had to add another half bottle of very dry red wine to get it to my liking.
Excellent!
A great, tasty treat. Thanks!
